title: First Vatican Council
text:
The First Vatican Council () was convoked by <a href="Pope%20Pius%20IX">Pope Pius IX</a> on 29 June 1868, after a period of planning and preparation that began on 6 December 1864. This, the twentieth <a href="ecumenical%20council">ecumenical council</a> of the <a href="Catholic%20Church">Catholic Church</a>, held three centuries after the <a href="Council%20of%20Trent">Council of Trent</a>, opened on 8 December 1869 and adjourned on 20 October 1870 after the revolutionary <a href="Capture%20of%20Rome">Capture of Rome</a>. Unlike the five earlier general councils held in <a href="Rome">Rome</a>, which met in the <a href="Archbasilica%20of%20St.%20John%20Lateran">Lateran Basilica</a> and are known as <a href="Lateran%20council">Lateran council</a>s, it met in <a href="Saint%20Peter%27s%20Basilica">Saint Peter's Basilica</a> in the Vatican, hence its name. Its best-known decision is its definition of <a href="papal%20infallibility">papal infallibility</a>.
The council was convoked to deal with the contemporary "problems" of the rising influence of <a href="rationalism">rationalism</a>, <a href="anarchism">anarchism</a>, <a href="communism">communism</a>, <a href="socialism">socialism</a>, <a href="liberalism">liberalism</a>, and <a href="materialism">materialism</a>. Its purpose was, besides this, to define the <a href="Catholic%20theology">Catholic doctrine</a> concerning the Church of Christ. There was discussion and approval of only two constitutions: the Dogmatic Constitution on the Catholic Faith () and the First Dogmatic Constitution on the Church of Christ (), the latter dealing with the <a href="papal%20primacy">primacy</a> and <a href="papal%20infallibility">infallibility</a> of the <a href="Bishop%20of%20Rome">Bishop of Rome</a>. The first matter brought up for debate was the dogmatic draft of Catholic doctrine against the manifold errors due to rationalism. The Council condemned rationalism, secularism, liberalism, naturalism, modernism, materialism and pantheism. The Catholic Church was on the defensive against the main ideology of the 19th century.
Background.
As early as late 1864, Pius IX had commissioned the <a href="Cardinal%20%28Catholic%20Church%29">cardinals</a> resident in Rome to tender him their opinions as to the advisability of a council. The majority pronounced in favour of the scheme, dissenting voices being rare. After March 1865 the convocation of the council was no longer in doubt. Special bulls were reportedly issued with invitations to <a href="Eastern%20Orthodox%20Church">Eastern Orthodox</a> and <a href="Protestantism">Protestant</a> clerics as well as to other non-Catholics, but apparently none accepted the invitations.
The Council was summoned by the pope by a <a href="Papal%20bull">bull</a> on 29 June 1868. The first session was held in <a href="St.%20Peter%27s%20Basilica">St. Peter's Basilica</a> on 8 December 1869. Preliminary sessions dealt with general administrative matters and committee assignments. <a href="Bishop%20in%20the%20Catholic%20Church">Bishop</a> <a href="Bernard%20John%20McQuaid">Bernard John McQuaid</a> complained of rainy weather, inadequate heating facilities, and boredom. Bishop <a href="James%20Roosevelt%20Bayley">James Roosevelt Bayley</a> of Newark, New Jersey, noted the high prices in Rome. When <a href="Richard%20Monckton%20Milnes%2C%201st%20Baron%20Houghton">Lord Houghton</a> asked <a href="Henry%20Edward%20Manning">Cardinal Manning</a> what had been going on, he answered: "Well, we meet, and we look at one another, and then we talk a little, but when we want to know what we have been doing, we read "<a href="The%20Times">The Times</a>".
Papal infallibility.
The object of the council was a mystery for a while. The first revelation was given, in February 1869, by an article in , a <a href="Society%20of%20Jesus">Jesuit</a> periodical. It claimed, as the view of many Catholics in France, that the council would be of very brief duration, since the majority of its members were in agreement, and mentioned the proclamation of papal infallibility. Factions around the proposal arose across Europe, and some Italians even proposed setting up a rival council in <a href="Naples">Naples</a>. However, before the Council met all became quiet in view of the studied vagueness of the invitation.
Pope Pius defined as <a href="Dogma%20in%20the%20Catholic%20Church">dogma</a> the <a href="Immaculate%20Conception">Immaculate Conception</a> of <a href="Mary%2C%20mother%20of%20Jesus">Mary, the mother of Jesus</a>, in 1854. However, the proposal to define papal infallibility itself as dogma met with resistance, not because of doubts about the substance of the proposed definition, but because some considered it inopportune to take that step at that time. <a href="Richard%20McBrien">Richard McBrien</a> divides the bishops attending Vatican I into three groups. The first group, which McBrien calls the "active infallibilists", was led by <a href="Henry%20Edward%20Manning">Henry Edward Manning</a> and <a href="Ignatius%20von%20Senestr%C3%A9y">Ignatius von Senestréy</a>. According to McBrien, the majority of the bishops were not so much interested in a formal definition of papal infallibility as they were in strengthening papal authority and, because of this, were willing to accept the agenda of the infallibilists. A minority, some 10% of the bishops, McBrien says, opposed the proposed definition of papal infallibility on both ecclesiastical and pragmatic grounds, because, in their opinion, it departed from the ecclesiastical structure of the <a href="early%20Christianity">early Christian</a> church. From a pragmatic perspective, they feared that defining papal infallibility would alienate some Catholics, create new difficulties for union with non-Catholics, and provoke interference by governments in ecclesiastical affairs. Those who held this view included most of the German and Austro-Hungarian bishops, nearly half of the Americans, one third of the French, most of the <a href="Chaldean%20Catholic%20Church">Chaldaeans</a> and <a href="Melkite%20Greek%20Catholic%20Church">Melkites</a>, and a few <a href="Armenian%20Catholic%20Church">Armenians</a>. Only a few bishops appear to have had doubts about the dogma itself.
On 24 April 1870, the dogmatic constitution on the Catholic faith was adopted unanimously. The draft presented to the Council on 8 March drew no serious criticism, but a group of 35 English-speaking bishops, who feared that the opening phrase of the first chapter, "" ('Holy Roman Catholic Church'), might be construed as favouring the <a href="Anglicanism">Anglican</a> <a href="branch%20theory">branch theory</a>, later succeeded in having an additional adjective inserted, so that the final text read: "" ('Holy Catholic Apostolic Roman Church'). The constitution thus set forth the teaching of the "Holy Catholic Apostolic Roman Church" on God, revelation and faith.
There was stronger opposition to the draft constitution on the nature of the church, which at first did not include the question of papal infallibility, but the majority party in the council, whose position on this matter was much stronger, brought it forward. It was decided to postpone discussion of everything in the draft except infallibility. The decree did not go forward without controversy; Cardinal , Archbishop of Bologna, proposed adding that the pope is assisted by "the counsel of the bishops manifesting the tradition of the churches". Pius IX rejected Guidi's view of the bishops as witnesses to the tradition, maintaining: "I am the tradition".
On 13 July 1870, a preliminary vote on the section on infallibility was held in a general congregation: 451 voted simply in favour (), 88 against (), and 62 in favour but on condition of some amendment (). This made evident what the final outcome would be, and some 60 members of the opposition left Rome so as not to be associated with approval of the document. The final vote, with a choice only between and , was taken on 18 July 1870, with 433 votes in favour and only 2 against defining as a dogma the infallibility of the pope when speaking . The two votes in opposition were cast by Bishops <a href="Aloisio%20Riccio">Aloisio Riccio</a> and <a href="Edward%20Fitzgerald%20%28bishop%29">Edward Fitzgerald</a>.
The dogmatic constitution states, in chapter 4:9, that the Pope has "full and supreme power of jurisdiction over the whole Church" (chapter 3:9); and that, when he:
None of the bishops who had argued that proclaiming the definition was inopportune refused to accept it. Some Catholics, mainly of German language and largely inspired by the historian <a href="Ignaz%20von%20D%C3%B6llinger">Ignaz von Döllinger</a>, formed the separate <a href="Old%20Catholic%20Church">Old Catholic Church</a> in protest; von Döllinger did not formally join the new group himself.
Suspension and aftermath.
Discussion of the rest of the document on the nature of the church was to continue when the bishops returned after a summer break. However, in the meanwhile the <a href="Franco-Prussian%20War">Franco-Prussian War</a> broke out. With the swift German advance and the capture of <a href="Napoleon%20III">Emperor Napoleon III</a>, French troops protecting papal rule in Rome withdrew from the city.
Consequently, on 20 October 1870, one month after the Kingdom of Italy <a href="Capture%20of%20Rome">had occupied Rome</a>, Pope Pius IX, who then considered himself a prisoner in the Vatican, issued the bull , adjourning the Council indefinitely. While some proposed to continue the council in the Belgian city of <a href="Mechlin">Mechlin</a>, it was never reconvened. The Council was formally closed in 1960 by <a href="Pope%20John%20XXIII">Pope John XXIII</a>, prior to the formation of the <a href="Second%20Vatican%20Council">Second Vatican Council</a>.
Meanwhile, in reaction to the political implications of the doctrine of infallibility on the <a href="secularism">secular</a> states, some took rapid action. <a href="Austria">Austria</a> annulled the <a href="Concordat">Concordat</a> arranged with the <a href="Roman%20Curia">Curia</a> in 1855. In <a href="Prussia">Prussia</a> the anti-Catholic "<a href="Kulturkampf">Kulturkampf</a>" broke out immediately afterwards, and in France the synod so accentuated the power of <a href="ultramontanism">ultramontanism</a> (an emphasis on the powers of the Pope), that the <a href="French%20Third%20Republic">French Third Republic</a> took steps to curb it by revoking the <a href="Concordat%20of%201801">Concordat of 1801</a> and completely separating the Church from the State.
